title: Parallel Ensemble-Kalman-Inversion
text:
Note



This website contains supplementary material to my poster about “Parallel Ensemble-Kalman-Inversion using Gaussian Random Fields” presented at the 26th EM Induction Workshop, Beppu, Japan, 2024.


This study presents a parallel implementation of the Ensemble-Kalman-Inversion (EKI) algorithm (Iglesias et al. (2013), Iglesias (2016), Muir & Tsai (2020)), tailored for 2-D magnetotelluric (MT) inversion. We employ Gaussian Random Fields (GRF) for effective parametrization of the electrical conductivity. In our numerical approach we utilized the Julia Finite Element package Gridap.jl (Badia & Verdugo (2020)) which ensures accurate mapping of GRFs onto the Finite Element (FE) space. Furthermore, we customized the Gridap.jl package to meet the specific requirements of 2-D MT modeling, resulting in the development of GridapMT.jl.

title: 2  Fundamentals
text:
2.1 The EKI Algorithm
The EKI algorithm can be split into the following steps:
Initialization Draw \(\{ m_{n}^{(j)}\}_{j=1}^J\) ensemble members from a prior distribution. Set \(\rho \in (0,1)\) and \(\tau > 1/\rho\). Then for \(n=0,1 \dots\)
Prediction Evaluate \(w_n^{(j)} = G(m_n^{(j)})\) and calculate the mean value \(\overline{w}_n\).
Termination If \(||\Gamma^{-1/2}(\mathbf d - \overline w_n) || \le \tau \eta\), terminate and output the ensemble mean \(\overline m_n\) as solution. \(\Gamma\) encodes the measurement precision so that the misfit is weighted.
Analysis At each iteration, an ensemble of perturbed data \(\{ y_{n}^{(j)}\}_{j=1}^J\) is generated with additional noise \(y_n^{(j)} = d + \eta\).
The update at iteration \(n\) is given by
\[
m_{n+1}^{(j)} = m_{n}^{(j)} + C_{n}^{mw} \left(  
C_{n}^{ww} + \alpha_{n}\Gamma
\right) ^{-1}
( y_{n}^{(j)} - w_{n}^{(j)} )
\tag{2.2}\] where \[
\begin{align}
C_{n}^{ww}(\cdot) & = \frac{1}{J-1} \sum_{j=1}^{J} \left( G(m_{n}^{(j)}) - \overline{w}_{n} \right) \left< G(m_{n}^{(j)}) - \overline{w}_{n}, \cdot \right>_{Y} \\
C_{n}^{mw}(\cdot) & = \frac{1}{J-1} \sum_{j=1}^{J} \left( m_{n}^{(j)} - \overline{m}_{n} \right) \left< G(m_{n}^{(j)}) - \overline{w}_{n}, \cdot \right>_{Y}
\end{align}
\] are covariance operators, \(G(m_n^{(j)})\) is the forward operator applied to the \(j\)-th ensemble member at iteration \(n\), and \(\Gamma\) is an operator that encodes the measurement precision.
For constructing the inverse in 2.2 we employ a low-rank approximation of \(C^{ww}_n\) to compute the eigen decomposition of the operator.

title: 3  The Matérn Covariance Function
text:
The Matérn covariance between measurements taken at two points separated by \(\rho = \|x - y\|\) distance units is given by \[
C(x,y) = \sigma  \frac{2^{1-\nu}}{\Gamma(\nu)} \left( \frac{\rho}{\lambda} \right)^{\nu}K_{\nu} \left( \frac{\rho}{\lambda} \right) ,
\tag{3.1}\] where \(\Gamma\) is the gamma function, \(K_{\nu }\) is the modified Bessel function of the second kind, \(\lambda\) (correlation length) and \(\nu\) (smoothness) are positive parameters of the covariance.
Figure 3.1 gives examples of the Matérn function for different values of correlation length and smoothness.






Figure 3.1: Examples of the Matérn Covariance Function



When the GRF is evaluated to generate the prior ensemble, the correlaton length and smoothness parameters are being kept fixed.
We note further, that the choice of the Matérn parameters should refelct the a priori knowledge about the spatial features of the model.
Finally, we emphasize the Invariance Subspace property which states, that the EKI results tend to converge towards a model which lies in the span of the initial EKI ensemble.
